questions.text: What is the Drug of choice for Hyperthyroidism in first trimester of Pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Propylthiouracil Carbimazole & Methimazole are thioamides group drug and these drugs have risk of teratogenicity (Aplasia cutis) so not safe in first trimester of pregnancy. In second and third trimester they can be used as PTU is not a safe drug overall because of risk of agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with chest pain. ECG of the patient confirms it to be non ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following drug useful in this patient acts by inhibiting platelet aggregation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clopidogrel Treatment of NON-STEMI: MONA • Morphine • Oxygen • NTG • Anti-platelets Clopidogrel is irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor, used as antiplatelet drug. Most commonly used antiplatelet is Aspirin, which is irreversible COX inhibitor. Streptokinase is fibrinolytic agent, used in STEMI patients. Heparin & warfarin are anticoagulants.

questions.text: A patient with chronic stable angina presents with pedal edema, breathlessness and other symptoms of heart failure. Which of the following drug can increase longevity in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lisinopril Drugs increasing survival or inhibits mortality via inhibiting remodelling risk in CHF patients are: • RAAS inhibitors- ACE inhibitors (pril), ARBs (sartans) & Spironolactone • Sympatholytics- Beta blockers • Vasadilators- Hydralazine Other drugs used in CHF are providing symptomatic relief only.

questions.text: A female washing clothes in cold water exhibited color change of her hands from pallor to red. Which of the following drug is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Calcium channel blockers It’s a case of peripheral vascular disease (PVD). Drugs used in PVD are vasodilators. CCBs (dipines) are best arterial dilators for treating these patients and avoid risk.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is involved in peripheral conversion of T4 to T3?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5’ deiodinase 5’ deiodinase T4 is the circulating form and T3 is the active form. T4 is converting to T3 in peripheral tissues. Enzyme for this process is 5’ deiodinase. Antithyroid drug inhibiting this enzyme is Propylthiouracil.

questions.text: A 25 year old female presented with mania. History revealed that her father is taking medications for bipolar disorder. Which of the following drug will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lithium Lithium In BPD patients the best mood stabilizer is lithium. It is also having anti-maniac property. Valproate is given for rapid cyclers and lamotrigine is used during depressive phase of BPD. Overall best anti-maniac in acute condition is atypical antipsychotics.

choices.text: It is the dose at which 50% of animals will die
It is the dose at which 50 animals will die
It is the dose at which 50% patients will get the desired response
It is drug, that will be effective at 50% dose

questions.text: What does LD50 signifies
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is the dose at which 50% of animals will die LD50: Median lethal dose- The dose at which 50% of subjects will die. ED50: Median effective dose- The dose at which 50% of subjects will get desired effect. Therapeutic Index (TI): LD50/ED50- It is the marker for safety margin. Narrow therapeutic index means the drug is having more risk of toxicity eg. Lithium, phenytoin, digoxin.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used for pain relief in arthritis acts by both opioid and non opioid mechanisms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tramadol Tramadol is mixed analgesic, acts via opioid and non-opioid both mechanisms. In non-opioid mechanism it is SNRI (serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor). It is commonly used opioid as analgesic. PCM, Ketorolac & Diclofenac are NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 25 year old male has frequent visits to rural areas and need to eat outside food. During one such visit, he developed loose stools. Which of the following drug should be used to manage this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metronidazole It’s a case of infectious diarrhoea. For infectious diarrhoea antimicrobial agents can be used. Loperamide & Diphenoxylate are peripheral opioids, used as antimotility drugs but not to be used for infectious diarrhoea. Octreotide is used as anti-secretory agent in secretory diarrhoea.

questions.text: All of the following are Side effects of Ritodrine except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypoglycemia Ritodrine is beta-2 agonist, used as tocolytic agent. Beta-2 agonists side effects are- • Tremors • Tachycardia • Restlessness • Hypokalemia • Hyperglycemia due to decrease insulin secretion • Hypotension & edema due to vasodilation

questions.text: A female visits the OPD to get rid of tobacco addiction. Which of the following drug will you prescribe?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vareniciline Drugs used for anti-smoking purpose are: • NRT (Nicotine replacement therapy) • Varenicline- partial nicotine receptor agonist • Bupropion- DNRI • Clonidine • Nortriptyline

questions.text: A known hypertensive patient came to emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. Her BP was 220/140. Among the option given below, which drug should not be used in treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) I.V.Mannitol It’s a case of HTN emergency. First line drugs used are nicardipine & sodium nitroprusside. Esmolol is fastest acting beta blocker so also used in emergencies. Mannitol is osmotic diuretic and it increases plasma volume. Mannitol is not safe in severe HTN, CHF, Pulmonary edema patients because of this risk.

questions.text: A patient with history of drug abuse presented to emergency in comatose state. Vitals recorded were: Respiratory rate 8/min, BP: 90/60 mmHg, Pulse 52 bpm. On examination, there was pin point pupil. What is the probable poisoning agent in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Morphine Cocaine is sympathomimetic drug and TCAs are having anticholinergic property so both of these drugs are causing mydriasis. Morphine is an opioid, which is having sympatholytic effect and miosis. In overdose it causes pin point pupil, hypotension, bradycardia and respiratory depression. Treatment is naloxone.

questions.text: A known patient of bronchial asthma was started on treatment with an anti-glaucoma drug. During the course of treatment, asthma worsened. Which drug is likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Timolol Beta blockers are not safe in asthma patients as there is risk of bronchoconstriction. Timolol being a nonselective beta blocker can worsen asthma. Betaxalol is cardio-selective drug so it is safer in asthmatics. Latanoprost is PGF2alpha analogue, acts via increasing uveoscleral outflow is best to treat open angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient developed COVID-19 pneumonia and was treated. Few months later, patient presented with nasal congestion and swelling of face. There were black lesions on the nose bridge. A diagnosis of mucormycosis was made. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amphotericin B Mucor mycosis fungal infection commonly seen in COVID patients due to use of immunosuppressants. In diabetic patients it is very commonly occurring fungal infection. Drugs used in Mucor mycosis treatment are: • LAMB (liposomal amphotericin B) • Posaconazole & Isavuconazole LAMB is the overall DOC in these patients.

choices.text: It acts by inhibiting aggregation of platelets
It acts by Inhibiting COX-1 in both endothelium and platelets
It acts as a fibrinolytic agent
It acts as an anti-coagulant agent

questions.text: A patient presented with unstable angina and was started on 325 mg aspirin. What is correct about mechanism of action of this drug at this dose?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It acts by inhibiting aggregation of platelets Low dose aspirin (40-325mg) is irreversible cox inhibitor. It acts via decreasing TXA2 synthesis in the platelets so inhibit platelet aggregation. It is the best antiplatelet drug for ischemic heart disease and ischemic stroke patients. High dose aspirin is anti-inflammatory agent, which inhibit PGI2 synthesis as well.

questions.text: A patient with head and neck cancer is planned to receive radiotherapy. Which of the following anticancer drugs can result in increase in risk of toxicity caused by radiation treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cisplatin Chemotherapy causing radiation recall reactions are: • Dactinomycin/ Actinomycin D • Anthracyclines • Cisplatin

questions.text: A patient was started on lamotrigine 50 mg daily for treatment of epilepsy. Gradually, the dose of the drug is increased every 1-2 weeks to reach the final dose of 200 mg per day. This step up titration of lamotrigine dose is done in order to prevent or minimize the development of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Skin rash Lamotrigine is first line anti-epileptic drug, acts via inhibiting sodium channels. Risk of skin hypersensitivity reactions (SJS, TEN) seen with the use of this drug. To avoid the risk of dangerous hypersensitivity reaction in skin the dose should be increased gradually.

questions.text: Drug of choice for Legionnaire's disease is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Azithromycin Legionella infection is commonly occurring from air condition vents. It causes pneumonia. The drug of choice to treat this pneumonia is Azithromycin. Azithromycin is also DOC for pneumonia due to: • Mycoplasma • Chlamydia

questions.text: A patient with history of snake bite presented in emergency with symptoms of fatigue and irritability. Ten vials of antivenom were administered intravenously but the patient is still having difficulty in swallowing, ptosis and respiratory distress. What should be the next line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atropine and neostigmine Snake bite management: • ASV (Anti snake venom) – TOC • Cholinergic drug (Neostigmine) is used to improve muscular symptoms as it acts on NM receptors. • Atropine is given with neostigmine to antagonise muscarinic side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant is contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Warfarin Anticoagulants used during pregnancy: • Up to 12 weeks- Heparins • 12 week to 36 weeks- Warfarin • 36 weeks to 1 day before delivery- Heparins • Day of delivery- No anticoagulant should be given Warfarin is having risk of teratogenicity so not safe up to 12 weeks. Contradi syndrome occurs in which chondrodysplasia punctata occurs.

questions.text: A patient suffering for rectal carcinoma and on chemotherapy drugs develops severe profuse diarrhea. Which of the flowing drug can be given to control this diarrhea:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Loperamide Loperamide id peripheral opioid agonist having anti-motility property. It is used to treat non-infectious diarrhoea. Chemotherapy associated diarrhoea treatment: • Loperamide • Diphenoxylate plus atropine • Octreotide • Racecadotril

questions.text: Which drug Which Drug acts on the area marked?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Norepinephrine Noradrenaline/norepinephrine does not have beta2 action so it causes increase systolic and diastolic pressure. Also due to vasopressor effect it has reflex bradycardia effect.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl who was being prescribed iron supplements in form of syrup has consumed it in high dose and now having abdominal pain, vomiting. Which Antidote can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Desferroxamine Iron overdose treatment includes the drug which are iron chelating agents eg- Desferrioxamine, deferiprone & dexrazoxone. Iron dextran is used to treat iron deficiency anemia. Dimercaprol is BAL, used for Mercury, Arsenic & Lead poisoning. Succimer also used in lead poisoning.

questions.text: A female of 28 years of age comes to OPD with complaints of dropping of eyelid in evening time.. This patient is almost symptom free in morning and muscle weakness increases during evening time . As a physician you have noticed that patient symptoms improve after neostigmine. What is your most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myasthenia gravis This patient giving history of muscle weakness after exertion and the condition of the patient improved after giving cholinergic drug neostigmine. It gives a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. This test is called as ameliorative test for diagnosis of myasthenia gravis and commonly used drug is edrophonium/tensilon, which is a short acting cholinergic drug. d-tubocurarine (d-TC) is NM blocker so it causes worsening of the condition in these patients and this is called as provocative test.

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
A patient pretreated with Phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline
Increase in pulse pressure is produced by intravenous administration of isoprenaline

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the Phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A patient pretreated with Phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline Adrenaline is acting on all alpha and beta receptor so giving alpha blockers (phentolamine) before adrenaline leads to hypotension due to unopposed beta 2 actions on blood vessels. This experiment was done by Dale so this is called as vasomotor reversal of Dale.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with breathlessness, dry cough with reduced exercise capacity. On X ray examination, diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis is made. Which of the following drug can be used for the treatment of this condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Perfinidone • Pirfenidone is a synthetic pyridone drug. • The FDA first approved pirfenidone alongside nintedanib as one of the first drugs to treat IPF. • It is an antifibrotic agent with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that is used to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, which is a chronic, progressive form of interstitial pneumonia. • Mechanism of action is not yet fully understood, pirfenidone is proposed to primarily regulate tumor necrosis factor (TNF) pathways and modulate cellular oxidation.

questions.text: Which Drug acts on area 2?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aliskiren Drugs in this image are from RAAS pathway inhibitors: 1. Beta blockers 2. Renin inhibitors (Aliskiren) 3. ACE inhibitors 4. ARBs 5. Aldosterone antagonists

questions.text: A truck driver with HIV positivity develops cryptococcal meningitis. Which drug is best to start:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Liposomal amphotericin B Cryptococcal meningitis treatment- • Acute condition- LAMB plus Flucytosine • Maintenance therapy- Fluconazole

questions.text: Best treatment for Acromegaly?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lanreotide depot Octreotide & Lanreotide are somatostatin analogues and both are used in treatment of acromegaly. Lanreotide is available in depot preparation so it is having linger effect so it is best to treat acromegaly. Pegvisomant is growth hormone receptor antagonist, also approved for the treatment of acromegaly but it is having risk of visual side effects.

questions.text: A 68 year old male cancer patient on chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Filgrastim Most common dose dependent side effects of chemotherapy is bone marrow suppression. Neutropenia, anemia & thrombocytopenia occurs due to this. Drugs used to treat these conditions are: • Neutropenia- filgrastim & sargramostim • Anemia- darbopoetin • Thrombocytopenia- oprelvekin

choices.text: Drug C is more potent than drug B
Drug B is more efficacious than D
Drug C is more efficacious than Drug A

questions.text: Which of the following statements about drugs is false?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Drug C is more potent than drug B Dose response curve: • Height of the graph- efficacy (B=C>A=D) • Left side graph at 50% response- potency (A>B>C>D)

choices.text: Hemodialysis not useful in lithium overdose
Lithium toxicity can be exacerbated by thiazide
Lithium is fetotoxic if given to pregnant female

questions.text: A girl with known case of BPD is on lithium therapy. Which statement is incorrect in respect of lithium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hemodialysis not useful in lithium overdose • Lithium is narrow therapeutic index drug. Normal plasma level is 0.5-1.2 meq/lit. More than 1.5 meq/lit causes toxicity and hemodialysis needed at more than 5 meq/lit. • Diuretics and NSAIDs causes lithium retention. • Ebstein anomaly risk seen during pregnancy use.

questions.text: Drugs providing relief from Cardiac remodelling and increasing longevity ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metoprolol Drugs increasing survival or inhibits mortality via inhibiting remodelling risk in CHF patients are: • RAAS inhibitors- ACE inhibitors (pril), ARBs (sartans) & Spironolactone • Sympatholytics- Beta blockers • Vasadilators- Hydralazine Other drugs used in CHF are providing symptomatic relief only.

questions.text: Drugs used for chemo induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Granisetron + Dexamethasone+ aprepitant Chemotherapy induced vomiting: • Early vomiting- 5-HT3 blockers (Setrons) • Late vomiting- NK-1 blockers (Pitants) • Other drugs- corticosteroids, metoclopramide, cannabinoids

questions.text: A 38 yr old college professor suffering from depression comes to you with complaints of unable to get involved in process of intercourse with his wife. Which of the following anti depressant is best to be prescribed to him:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bupropion Sexual side effects due to anti-depressants are: • Loss of libido- SSRIs>SNRIs>TCAs • Priapism- Trazadone Minimum sexual side effects are seen with- Mirtazepine Bupropion is DNRI, does not causes sexual side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-dyslipidemic drug work by stimulating PPAR alpha -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gemfibrozil Drugs for dyslipidemia treatment: • Statins- HMGCO-A reductase inhibitors • Fibrates- PPAR-alpha agonists • Ezetimibe- inhibit cholesterol absorption in intestine • Colestipol- bile acid binding resin

questions.text: A female patient was having pain in her great toe(metatarsal joint) with swelling and redness present over it. She was treated with a proper drug therapy but her uric acid still coming out to be high. Which of the following drug can be given for fast elimination of drug from the body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Probenecid Uricosuric drugs to treat hyperuricemia are: • Probenecid • Sulfinpyrazone • Benzbromarone • Lesinurad • Losartan • Amlodipine

questions.text: A drug launched in market is in phase of marketing survillence is found to be associated with side effects. Which of the following parameter will tell us about drug safety
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LD50/ED50 LD50: Median lethal dose- The dose at which 50% of subjects will die. ED50: Median effective dose- The dose at which 50% of subjects will get desired effect. Therapeutic Index (TI): LD50/ED50- It is the marker for safety margin. Narrow therapeutic index means the drug is having more risk of toxicity eg. Lithium, phenytoin, digoxin.

choices.text: Inhibition of vit K dependent clotting factor II/VIl/IX/X
Direct inhibitor of factor Xa by binding to active site

questions.text: Dicoumarol mechanism of action:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inhibition of vit K dependent clotting factor II/VIl/IX/X Dicoumarol, warfarin are coumarin derivatives, used as oral anticoagulant. Coumarins act via inhibiting VKOR enzyme in liver and then inhibits factor 2, 7, 9 & 10 activation.

questions.text: A 50 year old, patient of type 2 diabetes mellitus was controlled on oral hypoglycemic drugs, This patient presented to hospital with hypoglycemia, Which among the following drugs can result in hypoglycemia in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glipizide Glipizide is sulfonylurea, acts via increasing insulin secretion due to ATP sensitive potassium channel blockade. Insulin secretagogues are having high risk of insulin secretion so hypoglycemia is very high with these drugs.

questions.text: A patient is taking platinum based anti cancer therapy for treatment of ovarian cancer. Which of the following drug should be used to prevent the nausea and vomiting in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Palonosetron Chemotherapy induced vomiting: • Early vomiting- 5-HT3 blockers (Setrons) [DOC] • Late vomiting- NK-1 blockers (Pitants) • Other drugs- corticosteroids, metoclopramide, cannabinoids

questions.text: In a patient with pregnancy induced hypertension, Drug used for treatment is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alpha methyl dopa Antihypertensive drugs safe to use in pregnancy: • Labetalol (DOC) • Mothyl dopa (2nd DOC) • Clonidine • Dipines • Hydralazine • Phentolamine

questions.text: A female patient was treated with clindamycin and developed diarrhea most probably pseudomembranous colitis. Which of the following is the likely organism responsible for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Clostridium difficile • Superinfection by clos. Difficile • Due to irrational use of antibiotics- Cephalosporins (most common), clindamycin, ampicillin etc • Treatment- Fidoximicin (DOC), Vancomycin & Metronidazole

questions.text: Mechanism of action of doxycycline is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Protein synthesis inhibitor Doxycycline is a tetracycline, acts via inhibiting the protein synthesis. It binds to 30S ribosome and then inhibits binding of aminoacyl t-RNA to A-site of m-RNA ribosome complex.

questions.text: A 56 year old patient who is a known case of hypertension was being treated with antihypertensive drugs. He is having chronic cough since 2 weeks. He was started on antimicrobials but cough did not resolve, Which of the following antihypertensive drug may induce chronic cough in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lisinopril ACE inhibitors (pril) are increasing bradykinin level by inhibiting it’s metabolism. Due to increased bradykinin side effects seen are: • Dry cough • Angioedema • Rashes • Urticaria

questions.text: A 30 year old man travelled to Assam. After coming back to his hometown Delhi, he developed fever, chills and rigors and altered sensorium. The peripheral smear demonstrated the presence of P. falciparum. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intravenous Artesunate High grade fever with chills, rigors and altered sensorium is a diagnosis of severe and complicated malaria. Best drug to treat severe malaria is IV Artesunate because it is the fastest acting antimalarial drug.

questions.text: A person presented to emergency in comatose state after consuming some unknown poison. Excessive sweating is apparent and on examination there is bradycardia and BP is 80/60 meHg Which of the following is antidote for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Atropine All the symptoms like sweating, low BP, bradycardia are suggestive of cholinergic drug overdose. Atropine is muscarinic antagonist, DOC to treat this poisoning. NAC is best antidote for PCM poisoning.

questions.text: A patient has developed tuberculosis in which mycobacterium is resistant to rifampicin, isoniazid, kanamycin and levofloxacin, This tuberculosis is referred to as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Extremely drug resistant TB MDR-TB: Resistance against H plus R (first line drugs) XDR-TB: Resistance against H,R & 2nd line ATT including injectable aminoglycosides.

questions.text: A 2S year old male presented to emergency with head trauma due to road traffic accident. In hospital, the patient developed seizures. Emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mannitol Drugs best to treat various edema: • Cerebral edema- Mannitol • Pulmonary edema- Furosemide • Cirrhotic edema (Ascitis)- Spironolactone

questions.text: A 28 year old male went to Ladakh, developed shortness of breath. Which of the following drug will you use for the treatment of mountain sickness at high altitude?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acetazolamide Drugs used to treat various sickness: Mountain sickness- Acetazolamide Motion sickness- Hyoscine/Scopolamine Morning sickness- Doxylamine plus pyridoxine

questions.text: A female patient presented with greenish vaginal discharge. Clue cells were present and Whiff test was positive in vaginal discharge. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metronidazole Clue cells in vaginal discharge is a diagnosis of B. Vaginosis. Drug best to treat this case is metronidazole vaginal pessaries.

questions.text: A professor in medical college is teaching students about the adverse effects of a drug. Which of the following drug can cause Gynaecomastia in men?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spironolactone Drugs causing gynecomastia are- • Digoxin • INH • Spironolactone • Cimetidine • Ketoconazole • Omeprazole

choices.text: Inhibition of factor V and VIl
Inhibition of factor Ill and V

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tPA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Promote Fibrinolysis Alteplase, reteplase & Tenecteplase are recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (r-tPA), acts via promoting fibrinolysis. These drugs are used in STEMI patients and their main risk is bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following drug will you omit from the prescription of a patient with XDR tuberculosis in pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kanamycin As per WHO, all ATT can be used except aminoglycosides. AGs are teratogenic drugs which can cause fetal ototoxicity. AGs used in TB treatment are- Streptomycin, Amikacin, Kanamycin & Capreomycin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect of orlistat?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Steatorrhea Orlistat is an orally used gastric lipase enzyme inhibitor. It is commonly used anti-obesity drug. Main side effect seen with orlistat is steatorrhea (fat in stool) that can lead to faecal incontinence so fatty meal should be avoided with this drug.

choices.text: Directly acts as arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect tachycardia
Blocks both alpha 1 and beta adrenergic receptors
Primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
Decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth musles

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Blocks both alpha 1 and beta adrenergic receptors Labetalol acts as a competitive antagonist at both alpha 1 and beta adrenergic receptors. Alpha 1 blockade leads to relaxation of arterial smooth muscles and vasodilation. The beta 1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics acts on the site marked ‘A’ in the given image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hydrochlorothiazide The site ‘A’ in the given diagram represents a distal convulated tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide, thiazide type of diuretic acts on the DCT. They block Na+/Cl- symport in the DCT leading to an increase in Na+ and Cl- excretion. Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

questions.text: Elderly male with urine hesitancy and retention of urine comes to the hospital. Ultrasound shows residual urine of 130 ml. Which of the following drug is preferred for immediate relief of symptoms:
Cisplatin induced most common side effect is :

A 45 years old female is brought to the emergency department by her family members after an intentional ingestion of multiple iron supplements. What's the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition by oral route?
Chronic alcoholic patient confusion wernicke's encephalopathy, aphasia and unstable gate."
Drug of choice in facial nerve palsy?
In Bacterial vaginosis which drug is not used as per CDC recoomendation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Erythromycin The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend the following treatment regimens for bacterial vaginosis (BV): Recommended Treatments: • Metronidazole 500 mg taken orally twice daily for 7 days. • Metronidazole gel 0.75%, one full applicator (5 g) inserted intravaginally once daily for 5 days. • Clindamycin cream 2%, one full applicator (5 g) inserted intravaginally at bedtime for 7 days. Alternative Treatments: • Clindamycin 300 mg taken orally twice daily for 7 days. • Clindamycin ovules 100 mg, inserted intravaginally once at bedtime for 3 days. • Secnidazole 2 g oral granules, taken as a single dose. • Tinidazole 2 g taken orally once daily for 2 days. • Tinidazole 1 g taken orally once daily for 5 days.

questions.text: HIV mother, who is not on ART, drug given to neonate:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the case of a HIV-positive mother who is not on ART (antiretroviral therapy), the newborn is at risk of acquiring HIV during childbirth. To reduce this risk, the neonate is given prophylactic antiretroviral treatment. The current standard of care for preventing HIV transmission to the neonate involves giving both Zidovudine (AZT) and Nevirapine (NVP) to the baby for 6 weeks after birth. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), and Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). This combination provides effective post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent the transmission of HIV from mother to child during labor and delivery. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Nevirapine for 6 months: This is not standard practice. While Nevirapine is an important drug for preventing HIV transmission, it is not given alone for 6 months. The standard is a combination of Zidovudine and Nevirapine for 6 weeks. B. Zidovudine for 6 weeks: Zidovudine alone can be used for HIV-exposed neonates, but when the mother is not on ART, a combination of Zidovudine and Nevirapine is recommended. Zidovudine alone is not as effective in reducing transmission as the combined regimen. D. Zidovudine + Nevirapine for 6 months: This is excessive. 6 weeks of treatment with Zidovudine and Nevirapine is sufficient for neonates born to HIV-infected mothers who are not on ART. 6 months of treatment is not indicated unless there is ongoing exposure or risk factors suggesting extended prophylaxis.

questions.text: All of the following adverse effects can be seen after one years of using lithium therapy except:
Thalamic Dejerine Roussy syndrome, which drug is not used:
In Treatment of depression, all SSRI are used except:
A patient on some psychiatric medication developed a sudden hypertensive episode after after taking wine. Which of the following drugs is safest to use?

Four friends are planning a trip to ladakh. During their stay, one of them began experiencing symptoms of headache, nausea, dizziness, and fatigue. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment of this patient?
Cycloplegic for pediatric patient
Patient BP> 200 mm of Hg with intracranial bleed in NCCT head DRUG to be avoided?
Preoperative pheochromocytoma MEDICINE:
After taking antiemetic, patient develops torticollis. Which drug might be responsible for this:
HIV mother, who is not on ART, drug given to neonate:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the case of a HIV-positive mother who is not on ART (antiretroviral therapy), the newborn is at risk of acquiring HIV during childbirth. To reduce this risk, the neonate is given prophylactic antiretroviral treatment. The current standard of care for preventing HIV transmission to the neonate involves giving both Zidovudine (AZT) and Nevirapine (NVP) to the baby for 6 weeks after birth. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), and Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). This combination provides effective post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent the transmission of HIV from mother to child during labor and delivery. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Nevirapine for 6 months: This is not standard practice. While Nevirapine is an important drug for preventing HIV transmission, it is not given alone for 6 months. The standard is a combination of Zidovudine and Nevirapine for 6 weeks. B. Zidovudine for 6 weeks: Zidovudine alone can be used for HIV-exposed neonates, but when the mother is not on ART, a combination of Zidovudine and Nevirapine is recommended. Zidovudine alone is not as effective in reducing transmission as the combined regimen. D. Zidovudine + Nevirapine for 6 months: This is excessive. 6 weeks of treatment with Zidovudine and Nevirapine is sufficient for neonates born to HIV-infected mothers who are not on ART. 6 months of treatment is not indicated unless there is ongoing exposure or risk factors suggesting extended prophylaxis.
